column1: 1. GermanPolarityClues is a semi-automatic translation approach of existing English-based sentiment resources to the German language by means of three different datasets:
1.1 Translation of the Subjectivity Clues dictionary (Wiebe et al., 2005). Beispiel (GermanSubjektivityClues-Negative-220311):
Wort(\t)  Lemmata(\t) Part-of-Speech(\t)  PositiveRating(\t)  NegativeRating(\t)  NeutralRating(\t)  PositiveCorpusProbability(\t)  NegativeCorpusProbability(\t) NeutralCorpusProbability
1.2 Translation of the of SentiSpin dictionary (Takamura et al., 2005). Beispiel (GermanSentiSpin-Negative-220311):
Wort(\t)  Lemmata(\t) Part-of-Speech(\t)  PositiveRating(\t)  NegativeRating(\t)  NeutralRating(\t)  PositiveCorpusProbability(\t)  NegativeCorpusProbability(\t) NeutralCorpusProbability
1.3 GermanPolarityClues dictionary - as an extension of the Subjectivity Clues (Waltinger, 2010). Beispiel (GermanPolarityClues-Negative-220311):
Wort(\t)  Lemmata(\t) Part-of-Speech(\t)  PositiveRating(\t)  NegativeRating(\t)  NeutralRating(\t)  PositiveCorpusProbability(\t)  NegativeCorpusProbability(\t) NeutralCorpusProbability
II Multi-Domain Sentiment Lexicon for German (Hochschule Darmstadt)
The project was supervised by Prof. Dr. Melanie Siegel.
Approach: Sentiment terms were extracted from the MLSA corpus[1] and the pressrelations dataset[2], together with their polarities.
The average polarity for each term was computed, separately for each data source. In addition, contents of SentiWS[3] were added for evaluation purposes.
It lists positive and negative polarity bearing words weighted within the interval of [-1; 1] plus their part of speech tag, and if applicable, their inflections.
The current version of SentiWS (v1.8b) contains 1,650 positive and 1,818 negative words.
IV "Data and supplementary information for Ranlp 2017 paper on "Evaluating the morphological compositionality of polarity", Josef Ruppenhofer
There are three different data sets that are used in the experiments of the above mentioned paper:
- The main data set which derives from the combination of PolArt and CELEX.

It combines (i)  words from PolArt for which a morphological parse existed in CELEX with (ii) additional words taken from CELEX for which we added polarity annotations. The new words from CELEX were added so as to have a more sizable  share of the neutral class in the overall data set.
The main data set is split up into a train/test part (8400 items) and a dev(elopment) part (900) items.
train_test_lemma_polarity.txt - polarity annotations for the lemmas of the train/test set
wiktionary_lemma_polarity.txt - polarity annotations for the lemmas taken from Wiktionary
wortwarte_lemma_polarity.txt-  polarity annotations for the lemmas taken from Wortwarte
V Institute of Computational Linguistics, University of Zurich, Switzerland
Polarity lexicon: Nouns, Adjectives, Verbs, Adverbs
Authors: Manfred Klenner, Simon Clematide, Martin Wiegand, Ronny Peters
